Claim: Alien life has existed or does exist.
Scientific theories support the possibility of alien life.
The simulation hypothesis claims we exist as digital lifeforms within a network of information technology. If true, this could indicate the existence of extraterrestrial life.
Researchers and public figures argue that there is a 50-50 chance we are living in a simulation.
Other humans might be running the simulation outlined in the simulation theory.
The astrophysicist Tomonori Totani has created an equation that may prove that life (RNA), statistically, emerged at least once in each unobservable area of the universe.
If the Multiverse hypothesis is true, by necessity there is more than one Earth and thus, more than one human species.
In a multiverse, there are (close to) an infinite number of universes. This would drastically increase the odds of alien life.

While the odds of alien life would increase in some universe at some time, the odds of not finding them near humans or at a similar time also exponentially increase, meaning that life in the multiverse does not increase our odds overall of discovering alien life.
Behavior of quantum particles - these particles at this atomic and subatomic level can appear to be in two places at once - may indicate the existence of other parallel universes.
Even if there were parallel universes, it is unclear whether life in those universes would count as alien.
Scientists recently reported detecting signals from the birth of the universe which they believe may be signs of another universe ‘bumping’ against our own.
The logic underpinning the multiverse theory is flawed.
If the Multiverse hypothesis were true, then each human species would not be considered extraterrestrials by definition because they would be on their Earth.

Renowned astronomer Carl Sagan claims that while scientists are open to investigating the possibilities of the existence of extraterrestrial life, alternative explanations continue to fit our observations better.
There is no conclusive empirical evidence that supports the existence of alien life.
The resilient and adaptable nature of life suggests that life can thrive under conditions other than found on Earth.
Findings of so-called extremophiles have allowed scientists to scale back their list of requirements for potential (extraterrestrial) habitats.
Researchers discovered bacteria in Lake Whillans, which is buried 2,625 feet (800m) below the West Antarctic Ice Sheet.
Three recently discovered multicellular animals living in the muck of the deep Mediterranean seafloor ('Loricifera') do not require oxygen to produce chemical energy.

Tardigrades (also known as water bears) can survive without water for 120 years, freezing to -272.8 °C, heating to 151 °C, the vacuum of space, pressure six times as great as that felt at the bottom of the deepest ocean and doses of X-ray and gamma radiation that are lethal to other life forms.
Researchers found that most meteorites would simply get too hot (on average around 1,648 °C), destroying most amino acids and organic material during entry to the Earth's atmosphere.
Life could have come before the atmosphere became too dense.
Researchers found evidence of life in the driest location on Earth, the Atacama Desert. This discovery could have far-reaching implications for alien life (such as the search for life on Mars).
The environments life encounters outside Earth are much more extreme than those on Earth, for example, in terms of radiation and the absence of nutrients.

Life on Earth emerged in a particularly unique set of conditions and then adapted to current conditions. This would not be available on most planets - life would need to initially emerge in conditions analogous to or more extreme than those that, in every case found so far, require unusual and complex coping mechanisms to survive. (p. 2)
The conditions on Earth when life started were extreme from our point of view today, for example there was no oxygen in the atmosphere, similar to many other planets and celestial bodies.

When life on Earth emerged, the conditions on the surface of the Earth were that of radiation and lack of nutrients, which suggests that if a small area of any number of potential habitable exoplanets has a source of heat, liquid water, minerals, and chemicals, it could very well lead to a similar outcome.
There is no evidence that life can only survive in one specific set of conditions.
Non-biological alien life may exist in other realms that are accessible by neurochemistry including DMT experiences.
There is not a large enough data pool to assume anything about the probability of life occurring; our existence can be written off as sample bias.
It is hypothetically possible for there to be types of biochemistry that are not water, oxygen, or carbon based.
Recent discoveries have not only shown that life is possible in arsenic-rich locations, but that arsenic can even be used in biological processes.
There may be lifeforms based on silicon or sulfide.
Organisms, when genetically engineered to do so, have shown their ability to generate organo-silicon compounds.
Hypotheses of silicon's use for forming life are greatly overstated; as it oxidises to a solid, and has a poor range of handedness in compound form, silicon is unlikely to be suitable for life.
Methane-based, oxygen-free living cells could exist.
These lifeforms are only hypothetical and have no evidence to support them.
Currently, only water- and carbon-based lifeforms have been proven to exist.
Water is vital to the biochemistry of life.
Water is necessary for life because of its ability to act as a solvent.

Life requires thousands of interacting molecules at a minimum, and without a solvent to put them into solution, many of these interactions could not occur. H2O is more soluble than any liquid known to man, real or hypothetical, which makes it uniquely suitable for developing life.
There is a narrow band of optimal conditions in which biochemical activity is both vibrant and diverse. This decreases the probability of life creation/sustainability in many habitats.
Work in space has already proven that a set of conditions for the transport of lifeforms does not require ongoing support from Earth.
The International Space Station contains microbial creatures from its early days.
Many plants have been grown in space.
Even though ongoing support from Earth is not required, Earth-like conditions are created for life to survive.
In evolutionary biology, abiogenesis, or informally the origin of life (OoL) is the natural process by which life has arisen from non-living matter.
Complex life (especially civilizations) requires a more limited range of conditions, making it less likely.
While life on Earth emerged 3.5 billion years ago, it has only been complex for approx. 500 million years. This suggests that the development of complex life requires long term stable conditions.
The ability of life to survive after its formation is fully different from its ability to form in the first place.
Organisms may compete for the same resources, and occupy the same "niche", thus eliminating one another.

The Entire Galaxy once started out as nothing.According to the Big Bang Theory, the entire galaxy was created or formed from a space of nothing. Given that we as humans were able to form life from nothing at all it is entirely likely other species have done the same.
An ability or probability is not proof that something actually exists.
It is impossible to prove many theories of science completely.
Scientific theories often require falsifiability to make them reliable. As space is so large, it seems unlikely that this could be achieved.
The size, age, and properties of the observable universe allow for an extremely high number of planets on which life could emerge and thrive.
The Panspermia Theory posits that life was transported to Earth on asteroids or comets and started somewhere else originally.
Essential ingredients for creating proteins, nucleotides, DNA, and RNA - like free oxygen, phosphorus, sugar, boron, molybdenum - were not freely accessible on the early Earth.
Microbes, viruses and even worms can survive a journey through space. Some bacteria can even survive a relatively unprotected re-entry into Earth’s atmosphere.
The author of that study attributes their survival to the design of the locker in which they were stored. Meteorites have no such advantages.
A cave inside an iron meteoroid has similar characteristics as a metallic locker.

The constant thermal motion, radiation, and general "hellish" environment on the young Earth might have destroyed naked DNA and complex organic molecules. This increases the likelihood that life came from outer space, as it could not originate from the planet itself.
Life may have formed naturally (abiogenesis) on Earth as early as 4 billion years ago, protected in a deep marine hydrothermal setting.
The constant change and influx of energy would have created a chaotic system that had more opportunities to create self-replicating matter.
Local variations could have introduced a distributed network of organism-friendly habitats, or reproductive islands.

Life may have started naturally (abiogenesis) on the surface of Earth about 3.7 billion years ago, after the last heavy bombardment of asteroids. It's uncertain when the heavy bombardment of asteroids ended, but probably it ended not later than 3.8 billion years ago with the Late Heavy Bombardment.
The idea that life has come to Earth from space is improbable, compared to a simpler idea, that life was a product of early Earth conditions.
Having life come to Earth from outer space would require many additional theoretical requirements, yet it doesn't solve any gaps in our current understanding of life on Earth.

DNA originated from RNA, which has also functions other than coding. This would imply that the main process of life (reproduction) hasn't been subjected to any sudden shifts (like interstellar journey). It's been rather a continuous, unbroken slow process of matter organising.
The trip through space would subject any microorganisms to intense amounts of radiation from stars.
Life that evolved in the presence of high radiation levels would have evolved inherent resistance to it.
As we don't know the exact initial circumstances of the creation of life, claiming it started somewhere else just pushes the need for evidence into a philosophical realm or worse a belief system.
A discussion about how life on earth began is inseparable from one about life in the universe, if the Panspermia Theory is correct, and so it should be explored nonetheless.
Considering the time dimension of roughly 13.7 billion years for the universe, it is probable that extraterrestrial life exists.
When viewed through the lens of geological time or deep time, even a fantastically improbable event becomes a near certainty.
The question of whether the universe is finite or infinite is a matter of ongoing scientific debate without a final answer.
The Baysian indicator that the universe is infinite assuming the prior probability of an infinite universe is at least as high as the prior probability of a finite universe.
A finite universe would imply that the space-time has curvature over long distances. No such curvature has ever been observed despite large amounts of data; our universe is flat (Fermi Lab)
Primitive life only began on earth 3.5 billion years ago. This shows that life can take a long time to develop and so life still may not have developed elsewhere.
Using the Drake Equation, astrobiologists calculated that there are too many planets that could support life for there to have never been alien life.
The Drake Equation shows that even the most conservative estimates allow for a number of intelligent civilisations in our galaxy alone.
Given the speculative nature of the thought experiment, there is no way to establish reasonable conservative estimates, which makes it easier to manipulate the outcome.
Earth is a planet that supports life. There is evidence that other planets are similar to Earth, suggesting that there could be life of any number of planets that are similar to Earth.
Various observed planets are theoretically able to support life.
There are a total of 60 known planetary bodies which could be potentially habitable.
Besides Earth, Saturn's largest moon Titan is the only body in the solar system with lakes on its surface. Although these lakes are made of liquid methane and not water, life could be possible.
Enceladus has warm water geysers that point to a possible life supporting environment.
A different team of researchers confirmed the existence of water by giving additional evidence of the presence of hydrothermal vents.
Callisto has subsurface oceans that probably could support life.
Europa has an abundance of liquid water in under-ice oceans that are likely candidates for hosting life.
If liquid water exists elsewhere, then there is an increased probability that life exists elsewhere, and as the universe is billions of light years across, one would think this is quite likely.
Sulphur traces on Jupiter’s moon Europa may be the waste products of underground bacterial colonies (2003).
NASA announced the discovery of phosphine in Venus's atmosphere, a type of chemical that can only be created by a living source.
Late Oct. 2020 analysis indicates that the previously reported Venus phosphine detection-line may be an artefact.
Other planets exist in the Goldilocks zone, where a planet is neither too far nor too close to its star for liquid water to be present.

Among the more than 4,000 known exoplanets, KOI-456.04 is something special: less than twice the size of Earth, it orbits a sun-like star. And it does so with a "star-planet distance" that permits planetary surface temperatures conducive to life.
NASA’s Hubble has found water vapor on an "super-Earth" exoplanet located in a star's habitable-zone 110 light-years away.
Evidence suggests that it is possible that there is or at least was life on Mars.
Scientists found indirect, but strong evidence of past life on Mars in a meteorite that fell to Earth.

The meteorite from Mars was composed of minerals and carbon compounds usually created by microbes on Earth. Chains of globules, which are known to be formed by bacteria on Earth, were found under an electron microscope.
Some blobs, crystals or chemical oddities are not necessarily a sign of life.
The meteorite had crystals of magnetic iron oxide, called magnetite, which some bacteria produce.
Over the past nine years, scientists have scrutinized the Martian meteorite, and now only a few believe that it harboured Martian microbes.
Curiosity rover sediment sampling suggests that microorganisms are close to being discovered on Mars.
Mars most probably once had habitable atmosphere and still has liquid water reservoirs.
Scientists found that water had existed on Mars for 200 million years longer than previously thought, so there was more than enough time for the development of life.

In 2015, a team of scientists estimated that about 4.5 billion years ago at least one-fifth of Mars was covered in an ocean more than 450 feet deep. Such a water formation makes it highly possible that forms of life existed and are now hidden in the Martian soil.
Recent scientific evidence suggests that there is a permanently existing body of liquid water on Mars under the planet's south polar ice cap.

The search for evidence of past or present life on Mars is ongoing. Possible evidence has been suggested, but there is no consensus in the scientific community that evidence has been found for the existence of past or present life on Mars.
Whilst various conditions could support life as we know it, it is not clear that they can support the creation of life overall. This is because we do not yet fully understand how life comes to be.

Some scientists believe that plate tectonics are necessary for resource distribution that could sustain life. This adds a complicating factor that would limit the number of suitable life sustaining planets.
A planet or celestial body being theoretically able to support life isn’t evidence that there is or was life on it.

The probability of alien life is not just a function of the number of planets, but also of the probability of life developing on those planets. Although we know that the first number is colossal, the second number may be so small that the existence of aliens becomes very unlikely.
The presence of conditions that are necessary for life does not equal the presence of conditions that are sufficient for life - or the presence of life itself.
There are satelites inside our own solar system with presence of organic compounds galore but no sings of life whatsoever.
The universe is statistical and macroscopically homogeneous. This means identical probabilities lie across the whole area. If life came to be possible on Earth, the same possibility exists elsewhere.

Based on the assumption that only 1% of Earth-like planets develop life, and that on 1% of those planets, the life advances to an intelligent level (like it did here on Earth). That would mean there were 10 quadrillion (10 million billion) intelligent civilizations in the observable universe.
Based on the most conservative estimates of 5% (some go up to 20%) and the lower end of the total number of stars (10^22), there are 500 quintillion (500 billion billion) sun-like stars.
A study found that 22% of Sun-like stars harbor Earth-size planets orbiting in their habitable zones.
While 1% of Earth-like planets may seem like a conservative estimate, there is no reason to assume or expect that planets with similar conditions to Earth would develop intelligent life at all.

How life was kick-started on Earth has still not been completely discovered. Unless we know this, we cannot make claims as to whether other celestial bodies have conditions that are sufficient for organic life.

It is necessary to know all the steps in a process - and the chances of them happening - in order to determine its chances of occurring. Experiments so far, including Miller's, suggest mechanisms for only one step in an unknown process. A single unknown step with an essentially nil chance of occurring relative to the size of the universe would change the conclusion.
No mechanisms or experiments have yet demonstrated the abiotic generation of polypeptides or polysaccharides.
Since the Miller-Urey experiment in 1952, there has been a good baseline understanding of the general process of how life was kickstarted on Earth.
Our existence can be used to measure the probability of existence of life outside our solar system.
According to NASA, the Earth is the only planet in our solar system that is mostly covered in water. This is essential for supporting life.
In the context of the wider universe, the Milky Way and Earth might be unusually well-suited to support organic life, for example in terms of the solar system's metallicity.
The Earth is an electromagnet which gives it a field that protects life from harmful radiation. This may be an important factor in sustaining life.
Radiation may decrease the viability of life, such that major solar events are also a contributing factor in the formation of life.
Some believe that life can be sustained from radiation.
As known life is a product of the Earth's location, and constitution, differently located and constituted planets might be able to create different forms of life.
The same physics in a different environment could well yield unknown biochemistry.
Earth's biochemistry is based on the available raw material and energy.

In the Milky Way galaxy, there are about 75 billion red dwarf stars. Six percent of these red dwarf stars have an Earth-sized planet in the habitable zone, which is warm enough for crucial life sustaining liquid water on the planet’s surface.
Even the next star to our solar system, the red dwarf star Proxima Centauri, has an Earth-sized planet in its habitable zone, which could theoretically support liquid water.
Young red dwarf stars have high flare emitting activity, which can sterilize and damage the atmospheres of surrounding planets.
The Drake Equation presumes an unproven model of the origin of the Cosmos - the Big Bang.
Evidence indicates that the Big Bang hypothesis is correct.

The Drake Equation was not written for quantification, but for stimulating a debate. Thus it does not calculate anything, but proposes that there could be a possibility that alien civilisations exist.
Even as a philosophical question, the Drake Equation is a distraction from legitimate quantitative analysis beyond the parameters of the equation.
A debate can still be useful for exploring what is possible. The lack of adequate examination should not be taken as proof that something does not exist.
In the case of the Drake Equation, it is especially important to avoid speculation because of the unverifiable unknowns.

Specifically, values IV and V of the equation - the fraction of life-sustaining planets that develop life, and the fraction of life-developing planets that develop to sentience - are values we have no good way to estimate.
This argument is based on an appeal to probability, which is a logical fallacy. Just because something could happen does not mean it is certain to.
It doesn't fall under the appeal to probability as the argument did not say anything about something certainly happening, for it merely implied that it would be probable.
According to the Fermi Paradox, there is a contradiction between the lack of evidence and high probability estimates.

The Fermi Paradox is explainable by "The Rare Earth Hypothesis": if life were probable, we'd expect to find more evidence. If intelligent life were probable, we'd almost certainly have already been visited by aliens.

The Fermi-Paradox accepts that large barriers or filters could be responsible for the extinction of ancient alien life forms with high intellect. However, it does allow for both former highly intelligent aliens and low intellect forms of life that may be present.
It is very likely that extraterrestrial life consists of non-rational viruses, bacteria or algae, making it difficult to discover.

Based on the fact that viruses (or virions - viruses outside of hosts) can be found everywhere on Earth in enormously high amounts - the oceans alone contain an estimated 10^31 individual virions. We can infer that the most likely alien lifeforms are viruses.
The necessary technology for detecting virions, e.g., on rocks is still in development. Therefore, next to no research could be done on alien viruses or virions yet.
There is no scientific consensus if viruses are "alive" or not.
Recent evidence suggest that viruses are lifeforms, as they share unique properties with cells and evolved as separate entities.
Simple, single-celled life exists almost everywhere on Earth.
The creation of life by chance may well be such a fantastically improbable event that it has happened only once.
There is no evidence of life emerging independently on Earth more than once (i.e. all known life shared a common ancestor, LUCA). This is evidence of improbability of the emergence of life.
Some scientists believe that octopuses may have extra-terrestrial origins.
It might be improbable to happen twice on the scale of a planet, but on the scale of the countless planets in the vast universe, it might be a regular occurrence.
There could be different laws of physics throughout the universe that prevent life from emerging elsewhere.
Different laws of physics could affect the evolution of life as well as eliminate it.
Given that gravity plays a role in evolution, different amounts of gravity could impeded the development of life.
Different laws of physics may affect how stars burn, reducing the availability of heavy elements necessary for the formation of life.
Life as we know it has evolved on a planet with almost perfect conditions, so it might take a longer time for life to evolve on “imperfect” planets.
Since evolution is all about adaption, life in other regions might have been able to adapt to different laws of physics.

Since the laws of physics of today have developed over time after the Big Bang, we can assume that they need particular circumstances to emerge. This suggests that parts of the universe might have created different laws of physics.
One of the fundamental constants of physics - the strength of electromagnetism - does not appear to be constant throughout the universe.
Even if there are many different laws throughout the universe, that does not mean they will all preclude life from emerging, rather that life may just take different forms.
The differences in Planck's constant, a fundamental constant in physics, across locations is minimal.
Scientific findings suggest that the creation of life is not improbable.

A recent experiment recreated early atmospheric conditions on Earth and found out that RNA molecules (building blocks for DNA) were present after just a few days. This suggests that it is likely life could exist elsewhere.
Living things are complex. In order to form a living reproductive cell, it is necessary to have both the appropriate materials and fitting stable conditions.

There are so many variables that have to be perfect for a planet to hold life. e.g. presence of water, correct temperature, correct size to hold an atmosphere, right distance from a star, right place in a galaxy.

These necessary variables of planetary habitability makes life on Earth (or other planets) incredibly improbable, especially as the universe is constantly increasing in entropy (meaning the longer time goes on, the more unlikely it is that these conditions exist).
Biological life on Earth arose from the same physical and elemental bounds observed on other planets.

Given the theory of evolution, it stands to reason that the only life we might find in a particular environment would be life that is compatible with that environment. Life may take other forms in places that are not Earth.
The elements which make up life - such as carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, hydrogen, phosphorous, sodium, magnesium, potassium - are the most common in the universe.

Water is comprised of hydrogen and oxygen, which are the 1st and 3rd most abundant elements in the universe. From a statistical standpoint, water is more likely to exist than any other solvent, and therefore has the highest probability of being the solvent used by a lifeform.

That carbon, the key element in carbon-based lifeforms, is very stable and sufficiently abundant in the universe suggests that carbon-based life is highly probable under approximately Earth-like conditions.
The abundance of constituent elements necessary for life (as we know) is not sufficient proof that the organisation of these elements to manifest itself as life is common.
The galaxy is so old that other technological species living in it before us should be obvious by now (Dyson spheres, Von Neumann probes, colonization) yet we have no evidence of it.

After analyzing thousands of galaxies with NASA’s Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) space telescope, Penn State researchers could not find any evidence of alien civilizations on the basis of the emitted heat a highly developed civilization's energy supply would cause.

The further away we look, the deeper into the past we are seeing, therefore not finding something means that it wasn't in existence at that stage. If intelligent civilizations had formed more recently, information about their existence won't reach us for millions of years.
It's likely that an advanced civilisation would have highly efficient technology that would not lead to massive amounts of waste heat.
The WISE search looked for extremely-advanced Type III civilizations. Being unable to find any does not rule out the existence of Type II, or lower, civilizations. For example, Humanity is a Type 0.
It is unlikely that aliens exist in the galaxy because there is an absence of change in asteroids or planetary resources that would be expected if intelligent life existed.
There is no reason to assume that aliens would attempt to conceal their existence (p. 278).

Single celled organisms would likely be quite boring for complex life forms capable of intergalactic travel. If aliens had encountered Earth at this stage, they may have left to explore more interesting areas of the universe.
Humans have been searching for extraterrestrials since as early as 1896 and yet we still have no definite proof they exist.
Large numbers of researchers and astronomers study the night sky on a daily basis, yet have discovered no signs of alien life.
There have been many sighting of unidentified objects, with many flying in ways that no known human craft could.
The Rendlesham Forest incident may have been a sighting of an alien spacecraft.
There are plausible explanations for the event that do not involve any aliens.
The nearby Orfordness Lighthouse could have beamed light into the forest.
U.S. security policeman, Kevin Conde, might have caused the incident by driving around the forest in a police vehicle with modified lights.

The Rendlesham Forest incident may have been caused by the SAS as an act of revenge against the USAF, which previously interrogated and beaten up SAS troops and labelled them as "unidentified aliens".
The Phoenix Lights incident may have been a sighting of an alien spacecraft.
The Phoenix Lights were most likely individual planes that, due to their illusory contour, could have looked like a single shape to the human eye.
The official explanation of the Phoenix Lights was that they were military flares.
Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb has claimed that an interstellar object spotted in 2017 was evidence of an alien civilization.
There are alternative explanations for this interstellar object.
The Belgian UFO Wave may have involved sightings of many alien spacecrafts.
The photo that served as "evidence" for the UFO wave is an admitted hoax.

Mick West (a retired gaming programmer) and others have identified visual artifacts of cameras and other explanations of UFO sightings: low viewing angle, camera out of focus, night vision and triangular aperture artifacts, infrared camera zoom artifact, glare from airliner engines, and an artifact of a camera's de-rotation mechanism which corrects "gimbal roll".
The ping-pong ball movement effect observed in some UFO sightings can be caused by a combination of camera switching modes and performing gimbal rolls, as proposed by Mick West and others.
Perspective, etc. can cause the drift of a balloon being mistaken for fast airspeed, as proposed by Mick West and others.
It has been argued that Earth-based sightings of evidence for alien species have never been scientifically, methodologically studied beyond anecdotal reports of observations.
In August 1977, a strong pulse of radiation was recorded coming from near the constellation Sagittarius. This was unprecedented, and could evidence extraterrestrial life.
Little serious research regarding the search for aliens has been undertaken, as governmental and scientific authorities observe a de-facto taboo on the subject and its funding.
Television shows, like The X-Files and Ancient Aliens, portray extraterrestrial research as fictionalized which undermines its credibility.
Serious research regarding the search for aliens is unrelated to the pseudoscientific study of UFOs, which mainstream scientists have a justified taboo against.
US intelligence agencies have until mid 2021 to share what they know about UFOs, thanks to the COVID-19 relief and spending bill.
In the context of how old the universe is, less than 200 years is a minuscule amount of time.
Earthlings could be the first to appear long before the universe’s most fertile life-bearing years. Therefore, aliens might not exist yet.
Radiation in the cosmos has decreased. That has resulted in a universe that is 20 times more liveable today than it was four billion years ago, when life first appeared on Earth.
The universe is becoming "more livable" over time, and the existence of human beings used as supporting evidence in this claim, actually seems to support the opposite.

Red dwarf stars can live up to 10 trillion years. Compared to that, the approximate 13.8 billion years of the universe so far is a blink. As the universe is still in its childhood, the emergence of life might take more time outside of Earth.
Life may be about one thousand times more likely to arise in the distant future considering the probability of habitable, Earth-like planets forming over trillions of years.
Event A being "more likely" to happen in the future is not proof that event A has not taken place in the past.
The probability that humanity was the first technologically-advanced species to be created is less than one in ten billion trillion.

We might also be cosmological "late bloomers". 15 million years after the Big Bang, the cosmic microwave background created mild temperatures which made large parts of the universe habitable and established good conditions for life to develop.
There is no reason to believe that alien life would develop technology along the path human futurists have predicted.
The technology available today might not be sufficient to detect alien life.
Historically, scientific breakthroughs and new discoveries were possible due to technologic advancements.
Microscopic life could only be discovered with the aid of specialized equipment.
Up to around 100 years ago, we had no evidence for the existence of many sub-atomic particles.
Aliens may be transmitting signals that are not detectable with human senses or technology.

Radio transmission has been used only for 100 years by humankind and may soon by replaced by more advanced technologies. An alien civilisation could similarly have used radio for only or a short time or even never.
A range of radio frequencies in the Microwave Window are assumed to be highly useful for interstellar communication.
The use of radio waves has been growing rather than declining because radio waves make it possible to communicate across long distances, including between Earth and devices in space.
WiFi, Bluetooth, cordless phones, and cell phones all operate on radio waves and are used around the world, which was not the case 50 years ago.
Besides radio waves, there are other ways of free-space communication, such as laser (optical) communication.
Aliens may be using other means of communicating, which humans are not equipped to detect.
There could be alien civilizations that do not transmit strong enough signals to be detected by humans at this stage in our development.
There are limits to human perception.
Humans are only capable of interpreting data within the limits of their cognitive capabilities and comprehension.
Mysterians believe that there is a limit to human cognition; some thoughts are too complex for our brains. This may hamper our ability to reach out to aliens.
There is no reason to assume that human limits are absolute and that humans are incapable of improving their capabilities and comprehension.
Human perception is open to only a tiny share of the whole electromagnetic spectrum; this may inhibit our ability to detect some forms of transmission or signals.
Humanity has already put various satellites into space that can see beyond the visible spectrum and recognize - for example - radio, micro and X-Ray waves.

If an alien race were trying to communicate with us, and they had already found a means of communicating at far reaches, it is reasonable to assume that they would be able to reverse engineer our technology in order to speak with us.
Technology is expanding constantly, and so too is our ability to detect aliens.
Alien life could have existed in the past. The fact that humans have not discovered any evidence is irrelevant as they could just have "missed" the lifespan of an alien civilization.
Evidence of extinct species on our own planet (e.g., dinosaurs) is buried beneath the surface. This makes it very hard to find evidence of extinct species on/in other planets/solar systems/galaxies.

The Great Filters response to the Fermi Paradox states that alien life could well exist but may go through iterative cycles of extinction unless they have certain forms of intelligence or advancement.
To move from the fact that we haven't found definitive proof of aliens to the inference that aliens do not exist is an argument from ignorance.
Aliens could very well have already visited Earth, but before humans were there or advanced enough to document the event.
Researchers estimate that there are still over 300 undiscovered species of mammals, demonstrating how scientific investigations could fail to discover beings that exist.

The search for alien life is fundamentally different from the search for life on Earth because the conditions for terrestrial life are well understood, and this is not the case for extraterrestrial conditions for life.
This argument supports the idea that more scientific research into terrestrial species is needed, and does not provide evidence for the fallibility of scientific research in general.
Humans have not discovered a fraction of the universe, and therefore the evidence isn't representative at all.

As of April 2014, the Habitable Exoplanets Catalog lists 21 planets that have the best chance for life beyond our solar system. These have not yet received sufficient scrutiny to come to any conclusions about the existence of alien life.
Earth is not visible to all planets; studies have only recently been carried out that assess Earth's discoverability in our solar system.
The time span of human existence is so short on the scale of universe, that it is possible that alien life would not overlap with it, or even the existence of the Earth and Solar system.
Humans have only been able to detect alien life or been detectable to aliens, for a minuscule amount of time.

Previous searches have only covered 5.8 x 10¹? m5Hz2 of the universe's total "8D haystack" volume of 6.4 x 10¹¹? m5Hz2. This is a tiny fraction. (To put this in the context of Tarter et al.’s original comparison, the total volume of Earth’s oceans is 1.335 x 1021 liters. Since a cubic meter is 1,000 liters, that’s about the size of a large hot tub.).
If in an infinitely large universe, with many possibilities for life to have occurred, life still has not been found - then this may indicate that life is less probable than previously thought.
To assume that the portion of the universe observed from Earth is not representative of the broader universe is to assume Earth is somehow special, which is contrary to the Copernican principle.
The Copernican principle has not been proven yet.
If a hypothetical statement was true without proof, then any possibly conceivable statement would be true, including its opposite, which is impossible.
In most cases the argument against the existence of aliens is actually just an acceptance that convincing evidence for their existence is lacking. Thus, no definite argument from ignorance is made.
Although the lack of evidence is not decisive, it is justifiable to refuse to agree to a proposition until some evidence or support is provided.
Scientific conclusions should be evaluated in terms of their burden of proof. Grandiose claims, like the existence of extraterrestrial life, require more evidence to support.
There has not yet been any form of contact with extraterrestrial beings.
We have been listening for radio signals from other solar systems since 1960, and have never heard anything.

Fast radio bursts (FRBs) are mysterious pulses that emit more energy in a short time than the Sun does in 24 hours. Experts have theorized that they are produced by a far ultra-advanced civilization, trying to speak to us through signals we can barely comprehend.

The source of fast radio bursts (FRB) is unknown but natural cause proposals include: magnetars, black hole and neutron star collisions, a gamma-ray burst connection, especially energetic supernovae, and dark matter-induced collapse of pulsars.

According to the "Zoo hypothesis", aliens may be purposely preventing us from contacting them, so that they do not interrupt humans' natural development. In short, Earth might be kind of a "zoo" for aliens, to watch our growth as a species.

In order for the Zoo Hypothesis to be true, it would be necessary that the universe be dominated by a single highly developed civilization - such that it could force all other civilizations to stick to its rules.
It is not clear what use humanity would have to any alien civilisation, therefore it does not follow that one society would have to dominate to keep us in a zoo.
Communication can be extremely difficult or even impossible for various reasons.

According to the Rare Earth Hypothesis, Earth's circumstances are so rare it is conceivable that alien civilizations will be far away. This makes it very difficult to communicate or meet them even if they exist.

The distances in space might be too vast for contact. The furthest known galaxy is 32 billion light years away from Earth, and even the outer edge of our galaxy is 100.000 light years away. As no message can travel faster than the speed of light, this makes communication next to impossible.

The light that could tell an observer that life exists on Earth - which happened around 15.000 years ago - has not yet reached any observer further away than 15.000 light years. It has thus made it only 15% of the way through the Milky Way and only 0.00005% of the way to the most distant galaxy we know of.

The Rare Earth hypothesis assumes that galactic regions that are suitable for life are rare. By this logic, there is no reason why other life-supporting planets might not actually be very close. After all, our galactic region is apparently suitable for them.
True random distribution will result in some clusters close together.
That does not mean that we are in such a cluster.
In the context of the universe's vastness, even clusters might be characterized by distances between their individual elements that make communication next to impossible.
Based on the Great Filter theory, alien life could exist, but is incapable of technologically advancing enough for long-distance space communication or travel for various reasons.
The mother planets' resources could have been exploited and consumed before the civilizations were able to leave them.
Physical space travel and colonisation could generally be too expensive or inefficient.
Some sort of (global) catastrophe could prevent intelligent life from reaching a certain level of technology.
If Great Filter theory is true, then it is unlikely that humans will ever encounter intelligent extraterrestrial life, making the existence of such life trivial.
The time it takes for radio signals to broadcast throughout the universe is much larger than the time we have spent listening for responses.

Earth's (broadcast) signals have reached every star within about 80 light years (as of 2016) from the sun – about 8,531 stars and 3,555 Earth-like planets. That is a very tiny fraction of what is out there. Furthermore, it would take the same amount of time for aliens to answer.

This misunderstands what we are listening for. If an alien civilisation is persistently using radio waves to communicate, once they have started reaching us, they'll continue to do so for whatever period of time that civilisation used them.
Alien civilizations might have died long ago and any radiowaves they used might have long passed by Earth.

Assuming for the sake of argument that there was earlier intelligent life on earth, unless it were incredibly long lived, the traces left by it would likely not be sufficient to distinguish it from other geological events.
It is possible that communication with extraterrestrial beings may have been established, but this information was withheld from the public.
Some people suspect that NASA may be hiding evidence of UFOs.
It is unclear that NASA's incentives would align with such behaviour, as the existence of aliens would likely lead to an increase in their funding.
Some believe that the 'Oumuamua is an example of outreach from aliens.
Avi Leob, a prominent theoretical physicist, believes ‘Oumuamua is an alien object.
It is in the best interest of major world governments to maintain peaceful social order, and information about extraterrestrial life could create social disorder.
Conspiracies surrounding alien existence have existed for years. If these were legitimised, it may exacerbate other forms of conspiratorial thinking, and decrease trust in governments.
People generally indicate that they would react positively if alien life was discovered.
It appears that this positive reaction was solicited through reference to discoveries of extraterrestrial microbial life, not what we would traditionally conceptualise as alien life.
Without evidence of a coverup, well documented unexplained phenomena, or other reasons to suspect a global conspiracy, it is dubious to assert that one exists.
It is possible that extraterrestrial life would intentionally avoid making contact with humans, some of which have been discussed through science fiction.

Aliens might just not recognize us as a species worth getting in touch with, similar to the story line of Orson Scott Card's "Ender's Game". In the book, the so-called Formics are so different from humans that they do not recognize us as a sentient life form and without bother kill hundreds of millions.
Alien civilization could be millions of years ahead of mankind and look at us like we do at ants.

Earth is estimated to be about 4.5 billion years old; the universe is estimated to be about 13.8 billion years old. This difference leaves plenty of room for other species to get a head start compared to humans.

Even if we are like ants to aliens, it is possible to live symbiotically as is explored in Sue Burke's 'Semiosis'. The world explores how even with very different forms of consciousness, humans and alien lifeforms can eventually co-operate.
Humans domesticated dogs, there is no reason a suitably advanced alien species would not try domesticate us if we were useful to them.

According to the mediocrity principle, which can be interpreted as suggesting that there is nothing extraordinary about humanity in a universe that likely contains other species, there is no special reason for aliens to contact the inhabitants of Earth.

Aliens might refrain from contacting us as they are cautious. As the SciFi literature has it, even a vastly superior species might fall prey to unexpected problems, just as the martians in H. G. Well's "The War of the Worlds" unexpectedly die from microbial infections to which they have no immunity.
Aliens might be outright scared - Earth or its inhabitants may seem threatening to them.
Similar to how Stephen Hawking argues that we should stay silent and try to avoid contact with alien species, so might aliens stay quiet out of caution and fear.
The process of contacting other species itself might be dangerous, since it may reveal information to more advanced and possibly dangerous third parties.
If intelligent life were common, by a law of averages some would be cautious, while others wouldn't be. We'd expect to hear from the second set.
Aliens that have developed radio communication would likely broadcast their presence whether they want to or not.
If we are not looking in the right places, then we would not have noticed their radio activity yet.
Intelligence and curiosity are characteristics linked on a neuronal level. Were aliens intelligent enough to contact others then, like humans, they would likely do so.

Technological progress requires a constant gain of information and knowledge. Curiosity is the key factor that provokes this process. If aliens discovered and use technology, it is very likely curiosity is an attribute of their character as well.

Human beings evolved as curious creatures due to our particular environmental conditions, which reward curiousity and exploration. It is entirely plausible that life evolving elsewhere in the universe would encounter inverse conditions, that select against such a trait.
The behaviour of a significantly more intelligent being is completely unknown and unguessable to humans. We have not enough data to extrapolate.
There is absolutely no proof that alien civilizations are comparable to humans in terms of intelligence and curiosity.
